bibl.title: Lives of the Eastern Saints I
Thomas, Stephen, and Zota

event.desc: King Anastasius died in A.D. 518 (830 Alexander).
Justin became the new Emperor upon Anastasius's death in A.D. 518 (830 Alexander).
Jusin introduced the impious synod of Chalcedon. Those who did not assent, lived under persecution and exile. This began in the year A.D. 518 (830 Alexander).
The persecution reached Maro, Bishop of Amida in Mesopotamia and he chose exile over the synod of Chalcedon. He went into exile in Petra with Sergius, Stephen, and Thomas.

person.persName: Mare, Bishop of Amida in Mesopotamia

residence.note: Mare resided in Petra after the exile.
After the exile, Stephen resided in Petra.
After the exile, Thomas resided in Petra.
After the exile, Sergius resided in Petra.

event.desc: Bishop Mare sent Stephen to the Royal City to ask for relief from their distress in Petra. Stephen appealed to the patrician who would be empress one day, Theodora. Theodora appealed to her husband, who would be emperor one day, Justinian. He appealed to his uncle, Justin I who stated that Mare and his group could come to Alexandria.
Stephen delivered the order to come to Alexandria to Mare and his men as well as to Isidore, Bishop of Kenneshrin, also in exile.

Mare and his men found an old man who sold utensils for a living in the village of Mendis. He lived in a community of other religious exiles. Stephen and Thomas asked the man to lead them to the exiles.

person.persName: An old man who sold utensils and lived in exile in Mendis.

occupation.note: This person was a utensil merchant.

residence.note: This man resided near the village of Mendis.

personGrp.persName: The men and women who lived in exile in Mendis

residence.note: The men and women resided in exile near the village of Mendis.

event.desc: Thomas, endeavored to live as an ascetic in the pit near the village of Mendis, but everyone who heard of his plans laughed at him because he had such a privileged upbringing. He was a patrician who had his own estate and slaves and he was the descendent of the great patrician, Ishakuni Bar Br'y.

socecStatus.note: Ishakuni Bar Br'y was a patrician.

event.desc: Stephen intended to live an ascetic life, but he was sickly and feeble of body.

trait.note: Stephen was sickly and feeble of body.

event.desc: Thomas gave his keys to the bishop's cellarer and snuck out of his monastery at night to go to the pit, where he lived an ascetic life of prayer and fasting.
After six years of living in the pit, Thomas's trials left him physically ill and infirm.
Bishop Mare died in Alexandria

Stephen and the sisters of Mare received permission from Theodora to take Mare's bones to his own country. They also convinced John, who did not want to leave the pit, to accompany them on this journey.

occupation.note: Bishop Mare's sister was a deaconess.
Bishop Mare's sister was a deaconess.

event.desc: Mare's bones were put to rest in a chapel in Beth Shurla

residence.note: Mare's bones rest in Beth Shurla.

event.desc: Thomas went to the monastery of Mar John, where his sister Cosmo found him and pleaded with him to come home. He refused and remained at the monastery.

Stephen saw that Thomas was residing in the Monastery of Mar John and decided to join him, as did another monk who served under Mare, named Zwt'. All three men dwelled in the Convent of John Urtaya for two years.

residence.note: Thomas resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.
Zwt' resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.
Stephen resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.

event.desc: John of Ephesus, who was a monk in the Convent of John Urtaya, observed Thomas's ascetic practices and had many enlightening conversations with him.

residence.note: John resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.

event.desc: Thomas, Stephen, and Zwt' departed from the Convent of John Urtaya after two years and headed toward Egypt.
Empress Theodora sent a letter to Stephen, inviting the monks to stay with her at court.

Stephen accepted the invitation and tried to convince Thomas and Zwt' to accompany him, but they refused and parted ways. Thomas wished to dedicated the remainder of his life to fasting and praying alone in the desert.

John of Ephesus found Thomas and Zwt' years later in the desert of Mendis by Mar Menas. Thomas's body was frail and sunburnt. He had dedicated his life to fasting, praying, so that by depriving the body he would purify the soul.

residence.note: Thomas resided in the desert of Mendis.
Zwt' resided in the desert of Mendis.

event.desc: Thomas died.
Zwt' died after Thomas.
Stephen lived a life of asceticism and abstinence, setting an excellent example for the king, queen, and senators.
Stephen died.
